title-group.article-title: Constituents promoting osteogenesis from the fruits of Psoralea corylifolia and their structure-activity relationship study

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Constituents promoting osteogenesis from the fruits of
Psoralea corylifolia
and their structure-activity relationship study

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Qingxia Xu, Youbo Zhang, Zichao He, Zhenyu Liu, Yingtao Zhang, Wei Xu, XiuWei Yang *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: State Key Laboratory of Natural and Biomimetic Drugs ( Peking University), Department of Natural Medicines , School of Pharmaceutical Sciences , Peking University Health Science Center, Peking University, Beijing , 100191, PR China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Leguminosae
Phytoestrogen
Promoting osteogenesis
MC3T3-E1 cells
Structure-activity relationship
Surface plasmon resonance
A B S T R A C T

The mature fruit of
Psoralea corylifolia
L. is a common traditional Chinese medicine used to tonify the kidney and yang, and as well as to treat osteoporosis. Systematic phytochemical investigations have established the most comprehensive constituent library to date, covering over 180 compounds. In this study, 109 chemical constituents containing 37 undescribed compounds were reported and incorrect structures of four known coumarins were corrected. The structures of these undescribed compounds were elucidated using spectroscopic methods, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 and Mo 2 (OAc) 4 -induced circular dichroism spectra. To identify potentially active compounds and investigate their structure-activity relationship (SAR), 89 constituents in the library were evaluated for their osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation activities in MC3T3-E1 cells. We found that coumarins, isoflavones, flavonones, and meroterpenoids were the material basis for
Psoralea corylifolia
-based treatment of osteoporosis, with some compounds exhibiting excellent activities. These compounds function via the estrogen receptor (ER) pathway and were natural phytoestrogen. Further SAR analysis showed that compounds with an intact isopentenyl replacement possessed superior activities, which was explained by their improved affinity with the ER.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author.
E-mail address: xwyang@bjmu.edu.cn (X. Yang).

However, studies on the anti-osteoporosis effects of
P. corylifolia
have mostly focused on its main constituents, such as psoralen, isopsoralen, psoralidin, neobavaisoflavone, bavachin, bavachalcone, and isobavachalcone. Systematic studies on anti-osteoporosis compounds from
P. corylifolia
and their structure-activity relationship (SAR) are lacking. Thus, this study aimed to carry out a systematic phytochemical analysis on
P. corylifolia
to establish a comprehensive constituent library and evaluate the effects of chemical constituents on differentiation and mineralisation of MC3T3-E1 cells. Furthermore, SAR was discussed, which was explained by surface plasmon resonance (SPR) experiments.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure elucidation
sec.p:
Bavacoumestan F ( 1 ) was obtained as a white amorphous powder, and its molecular formula was established as C 20 H 14 O 6 via negative HRESIMS at m/z 349.0709 [M – H] – (calcd for 349.0712), indicating 14 degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H NMR data (Table S1) showed an ABX coupled system at δ H 7.20 (s), 6.98 (d, 8.4) and 7.74 (d, 8.4), and three aromatic protons at δ H 8.20 (s), 7.86 (s) and 6.86 (s). The 13 C NMR (Table S2) and 2D NMR spectra revealed 20 carbons, including 17 olefinic carbons, two methyl carbons, and one oxygenated quaternary carbon. NMR and HR-ESI-MS analyses revealed a coumarin structure derived from psoralidin ( 13 ). The key HMBC correlation ( Fig. 2 ) was reported from H-8 at δ H 7.86 to C-10 at δ C 108.7, rather than C-1 ′ at δ C 114.5 (
), and confined the connection position of the isopentenyl group at C-6. The isopentenyl group was cyclised to generate a furan ring via chemical shifts at δ C 167.4 for C-2 ′′ and at δ C 100.3 for C-3 ′′ . The HMBC correlations from H-5 ′′ /H-6 ′′ at δ H 1.55 to C-4 ′′ at δ C 67.8 suggested a hydroxyl group at C-4 ′′ . Thus, the structure was successfully constructed ( Fig. 1 ), which was supported by X-ray crystallographic data ( Fig. 3 ).

Bavacoumestan H ( 3 ) and bavacoumestan I ( 4 ) were assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 16 O 7 on the basis of HR-ESI-MS at m/z 367.0816 [M – H] – (calcd for 367.0818) and at m/z 369.0968 [M +H] + (calcd for 369.0974), revealing 13 degrees of unsaturation. Their 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR spectra (Tables S1 and S2) highly overlapped with those of psoralidin ( 13 ), indicating their similar coumarin structures. The isopentenyl groups were located at C-6, as proved by the key HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-8 ( δ H 6.99 for 3; δ H 7.14 for 4) to C-10 ( δ C 105.1 for 3; δ C 108.1 for 4), and were cyclised based on their degrees of unsaturation. The presence of a dihydrofuran ring in 3 was confirmed by the C-2 ′′ chemical shift at δ C 87.9, and 1 H– 1 H COSY correlation between H-2 ′′ at δ H 4.93 and H-3 ′′ at δ H 3.35/3.22. However, only one methyl group at δ H 1.14 was observed, along with a hydroxyl methylene group at δ H 3.35. Accordingly, the structure of 3 was constructed as shown in Fig. 1 . The configuration of C-2 ′′ was assigned as S by its biosynthesis relationship with bavacoumestan B. The positive Cotton effect at 295 nm and 393 nm ( Fig. S6 ) assigned the chirality of C-4 ′′ as S based on the Mo 2 (OAc) 4 -induced circular dichroism (ICD) method (
). Thus, the absolute configuration of 3 was determined as 2 ′′ S ,4 ′′ S . Similarly, a hydroxyl methylene group replaced a methyl group in 4 based on its’ NMR data, but the methylene group was linked to C-7 by an ether bond, which was supported by key HMBC correlations from H-2 ′′ at δ H 3.84 (d, 12.0) and 3.69 (d, 12.0) to C-7 at δ H 162.2. In the NOESY spectrum of 4, the correlation of CH 3 -6 ′′ at δ H 1.25 and H-4 ′′ at δ H 3.59 indicated their cis orientations ( Fig. S2 ). Furthermore, the absolute configuration of 4 was assigned as 3 ′′ R ,4 ′′ S by the positive Cotton effect on 291 nm and 372 nm in the Mo 2 (OAc) 4 -ICD spectrum ( Fig. S6 ). Thus, the structure of 4 was established as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of bavacoumestan J ( 5 ), a white amorphous powder, was confirmed to be C 20 H 16 O 6. NMR data (Tables S1 and S2) analysis showed a coumarin skeleton. However, a terminal double bond replaced the methyl group of the isopentenyl group, and a hydroxylation reaction occurred at C-2 ′′ via HMBC cross-peaks between H-4 ′′ at δ H 4.83/4.72 and C-2 ′′ at δ C 73.5. The isopentenyl moiety was linked to C-6 via the HMBC correlation from H-8 at δ H 6.90 to C-10 at δ C 103.6 ( Fig. 2 ). The absolute configuration of 2 ′′ S was assigned by positive Cotton effect at 302 nm (Fig. S7) in the Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 -ICD spectrum (
). Accordingly, we established the structure of 5.

Bavacoumestan K ( 6 ) possessed the molecular formula C 20 H 18 O 8 and was also a coumarin. Three hydroxyl groups were combined at C-1 ′′ , C-2 ′′ and C-3 ′′ via chemical shifts at δ C 68.9, 79.2 and 73.5 (Tables S1 and S2) and HMBC correlations from H-4 ′′ at δ H 1.21 to C-2 ′′ /C-3 ′′ . However, the isopentenyl group was not cyclised based on 12 degrees of unsaturation. Similarly, based on HMBC analysis, it was connected to the C-6 position. Furthermore, the coupling constant value ( J ′′ 1,2 ′′ =7.9 Hz) (
) assigned threo configuration of OH-1 ′′ and OH-2 ′′ . Thus, we established the structure of 6.

Bavaisoflavone A ( 18 ), a white amorphous powder, was assigned the molecular formula C 17 H 10 O 4 on the basis of HR-ESI-MS data at m/z 277.0501 [M – H] (calcd for 277.0503), indicating 13 degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H NMR data (Table S3) of this compound contained two groups of ABX coupling system, which were δ H 7.91 (1H, d, J =9.0 Hz, H-5), 6.75 (1H, dd, J =9.0, 2.2 Hz, H-6) and 6.56 (1H, d, J =2.2 Hz, H-8); and δ H 7.76 (1H, d, J =1.8 Hz, H-2 ′ ), 7.53 (1H, d, J =8.5 Hz, H-5 ′ ) and 7.44 (1H, dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, H-6 ′ ). The 13 C NMR data (Table S4) and HSQC spectra showed the presence of a carbonyl carbon at δ C 178.4 and an alkenyl carbon at δ C 154.7. Based on the above-mentioned analysis, this compound was considered an isoflavone. The H–H COSY spectrum showed two coupled protons ( J = 2.2 Hz) at 7.76 (H-2 ′′ ) and 6.87 (H-3 ′′ ), which indicated a benzofuran ring. Thus, the structure of compound 18, named bavaisoflavone A, was established, as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of bavaisoflavone B ( 19 ) was determined to be C 20 H 14 O 4 based on the HR-ESI-MS ion at m/z 319.0966 [M + H] + (calcd for 319.0970). The 1 H NMR and the 13 C NMR data (Tables S3 and S4) of this compound were higly similar to those of compound 18, which suggested the same isoflavone skeleton of compound 19. Their differences were the presence of an allyl group, which was connected to the furan ring on the basis of the HMBC correlation ( Fig. 2 ) from H-5 ′′ at δ H 5.77 to C-2 ′′ at 134.4. Finally, the structure of compound 19 was confirmed, and it was named bavaisoflavone B. Bavaisoflavone C ( 20 ) and bavaisoflavone D ( 21 ) were assigned the molecular formulas C 20 H 16 O 5 and C 21 H 18 O 5 , respectively. NMR data (Tables S3 and S4) showed that they shared the same furan-containing prenylated isoflavone as compound 19. Based on two methyl signals at δ C 29.3 in compound 20 or δ C 25.3 in compound 21, a propyl fragment was added on C-2 ′′ . The C-4 ′′ carbons were hydroxylated via key HMBC correlations from CH 3 to C-4 ′′ at δ C 67.9 ( 20 ) or δ C 73.1 ( 21 ) ( Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, a methoxy group was combined to C-4 ′′ via the HMBC correlation from OCH 3 at δ H 3.01 to C-4 ′′ at 73.1 in compound 21. Therefore, the structures of the two compounds were determined, as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of bavaisoflavone F ( 23 ) was identified as C 20 H 18 O 5 based on HR-ESI-MS analysis, indicating 12 degrees of unsaturation. Similarly, the presence of a carbonyl carbon at δ C 175.3 and an alkenyl carbon at δ C 153.1 (Tables S3 and S4) suggested the isoflavone skeleton of compound 23. However, there was only one ABX coupling system, where δ H 7.05 (1H, d, J =2.0 Hz, H-2 ′ ), 6.83 (1H, dd, J = 8.0, 2.0 Hz, H-6 ′ ) and 6.78 (1H, d, J =8.0 Hz, H-5 ′ ) were observed. And δ C at 145.0 and 145.6 seemingly indicated a group of adjacent dihydroxy in the B-ring. Furthermore, there was another group of aromatic orthocoupled protons ( J = 8.8 Hz) for δ H 7.85 (H-5) and 7.00 (H-6), whose HMBC correlations to C-4 at δ C 175.3 were observed ( Fig. 2 ). An isopentenyl group was attached to C-8 via the HMBC correlation from H-1 ′′ at δ H 3.46 to C-7 at δ C 159.9. Thus, the structure of 23 was established, as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of bavaisoflavone H ( 25 ) was determined to be C 23 H 24 O 7 using the HR-ESI-MS ion at m/z 413.1595 [M +H] + (calcd for 413.1600). The NMR spectra (Tables S3 and S4) of 25 showed representative isoflavone NMR signals for a carbonyl carbon at δ C 178.0 and an alkenyl carbon at δ C 154.7. Two equivalent aromatic protons at δ H 6.82 (2H, s) and two equivalent methoxy groups at δ H 3.86 (6H, s) provided crucial evidence for the conclusion that the B-ring was 1,3,4,5- substituted. Further analysis of the 2D NMR spectra indicated that isopentenyl was linked to C-8 and cyclised to form a dihydrofuran ring, and that one methoxy group at δ H 3.78 combined with C-4’. However, only one methyl group of isopentenyl was observed in the NMR spectra. H–H COSY and HSQC analyses also indicated the presence of CH 3 – CH – CH 2 OH. Therefore, compound 25 was identified as 4 ′ -methoxy bavarigenin.

The molecular formula of bavaisoflavone J ( 27 ) was deduced to be C 25 H 26 O 6 based on the HR-ESI-MS ion at m/z 423.1800 [M +H] + (calcd for 423.1808). Further analysis of the 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR data (Tables S5 and S6) of 27 showed similar resonances to those of 26. The obvious differences between 26 and 27 were two groups of terminal double bonds at δ H 4.93 (s) and 4.81 (s); at δ H 5.05 (s) and 4.93 (s) in 27. The hydroxyl replacements were situated at C-2 ′′ and C-6 ′′ on the basis of HMBC correlations from H-10 ′′ to C-2 ′′ at δ C 76.3; and from H-8 ′′ to C-6 ′′ at δ C 76.6 ( Fig. 2 ). However, the attempt to determine the configurations at C-2 ′′ and C-6 ′′ using Mosher’ method, was unsuccessful ( Fig. S4 ). Therefore, the planar structure of 27 was proposed.

Bavaisoflavone K ( 28 ) was isolated as a yellowish amorphous powder with the molecular formula C 25 H 26 O 5 based on positive HR-ESI-MS. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data (Tables S5 and S6) implied that the skeleton of 28 was similar to that of neocorylin ( 37 ), except for the absence of the double bond at C-3 ′′ =C-4 ′′ in the pyranoid ring. The chemical shift at C-3 ′′ ( δ C 68.9) and the HMBC correlation ( Fig. 2 ) from H-3 ′′ at δ H 3.84 to C-3 ′ at 121.6 showed that a hydroxyl group was located on C-3 ′′ . According to 1 H– 1 H COSY between H-3 ′′ and H-4 ′′ ( δ H 3.02, 2.77), assignment of a methylene group at C-4 ′′ was obtained. The absolute configuration of C-3 ′′ was assigned as S based on the positive Cotton effect at 308 nm (
) in the Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 -ICD spectrum (Fig. S7). Finally, the structure of compound 28 was established, as shown in Fig. 1 .

Bavaisoflavone L ( 29 ) was assigned the molecular formula C 25 H 26 O 6 . The NMR data (Tables S5 and S6) of 29 highly overlapped with those of 28, indicating similar planar structures. The only difference was that a hydroxyl group at C-4 ′′ was observed via 1 H– 1 H COSY correlation ( Fig. 2 ) between H-3 ′′ at δ H 3.51 and H-4 ′′ at δ H 4.41, and a down-field chemical shift at δ C 68.2 for C-4 ′′ . The relative configurations of OH-3 ′′ and OH-4 ′′ were assigned trans on the basis of coupling constants ( J ′′ 3,4 ′′ =8.2 Hz) (
). In the NOESY spectrum of 29, the cross-peaks between H-4 ′′ and CH 3 -11 ′′ at δ H 1.13 suggested a cis -orientation ( Fig. S2 ). Finally, the absolute configuration of 29 was determined as 2 ′′ R ,3 ′′ S ,4 ′′ R according to the chirality at C-3 ′′ . Thus, the structure of 29 was established as shown in Fig. 1 .

Bavaisoflavone P ( 33 ), a white amorphous powder, possessed the molecular formula C 25 H 26 O 5 , as determined via positive HR-ESI-MS. The typical aromatic 1 H and 13 C NMR signals (Tables S5 and S6) suggested an isoflavone skeleton. However, the geranyl moiety NMR signals showed great differences from those of corylifol A ( 49 ) (
), where ten sp 3 hybridised carbons remained, except for 15 aromatic carbons. The 13 C and HSQC spectra indicated that ten sp 3 hybridised carbons contained three methyls, three methylenes, two methenyls and two quaternary carbons. The key HMBC cross-peaks ( Fig. 2 ) from H-8 ′′ at δ H 0.94 to C-2 ′′ at δ C 53.6; from H-1 ′′ at δ H 2.53 to C-7 ′′ at δ C 45.6, established the connection bond from C-7 ′′ to C-2 ′′ . However, an additional degree of unsaturation was in accordance with the molecular formula of 33, which indicated the presence of another ring. Further analysis showed that the epoxy bridge between C-3 ′′ at δ C 86.6 and C-6 ′′ at δ C 85.4 was required to meet 13 degrees of unsaturation and two rings. Thus, a structure was proposed. Fortunately, needle crystals of 33 could be cultivated from a mixed solvent of CH 3 OH and H 2 O after various attempts. Then X-ray diffraction analysis defined the absolutely configuration of 33 as 2 ′′ R ,3 ′′ S ,6 ′′ R . ( Fig. 3 ).

Bavachinone C ( 53 ) was isolated as a white amorphous powder. Its molecular formula was C 20 H 18 O 5 as determined via HR-ESI-MS at m/z 339.1227 [M +H] + (calcd for 339.1232). Upon analyzing its NMR data (Tables S7 and S8), 1 H NMR signals at δ H 5.51 (1H, dd, J =13.0, 3.0 Hz), δ H 3.27 (1H, dd, J = 17.0, 13.0 Hz) and δ H 2.77 (1H, dd, J = 17.0, 3.0 Hz), and the carbonyl signal at δ C 192.0 indicated the flavonone skeleton of 53. Singlet proton signals at δ H 8.03 (1H, s) and δ H 7.21 (1H, s) assigned to the A ring, showed that the isopentenyl group was combined with C-6. The key HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from CH 3 -5 ′′ / CH 3 -6 ′′ at δ H 1.50 to C-2 ′′ at δ C 166.1 suggested the presence of a furan ring, along with 12 degrees of unsaturation. Therefore, the structure of compound 53 was established as shown in Fig. 1 .

Bavachinone D ( 54 ) was assigned the molecular formula C 17 H 12 O 4 based on HR-ESI-MS at m/z 279.0660 [M – H] – (calcd for 279.0657). Representative 1 H and 13 C NMR patterns (Tables S7 and S8) of 54 showed a flavonone structure. However, methyl groups from the isopentenyl group were not observed. As elucidated from its molecular formula, compound 54 lost a propyl group, and an unsubstituted furan ring remained. Ortho-coupling protons ( J = 8.8 Hz) at δ H 7.82 and δ H 7.20 in ring A, made the furan ring locate on C-8. Thus, the structure of 54 was constructed and named bavachinone D.

Bavachinone F ( 56 ) was isolated as a white amorphous powder with a molecular formula of C 20 H 18 O 5 , indicating 12 degrees of unsaturation. NMR data analysis (Tables S7 and S8) showed that its structure was similar to that of anhydrobavachinone A (
). However, a hydroxyl group at C-5 was observed via key HMBC correlations from H-3 ′′ at δ H 2.90 and δ H 2.77 to C-5 at δ C 163.4 ( Fig. 2 ). The absolute configuration was determined as 2 ′′ S from biogenetic synthesis. Accordingly, the structure of compound 56 was established. The molecular formula of bavachinone G ( 57 ), a white amorphous powder, was confirmed to be C 20 H 18 O 5 . Based on NMR data (Tables S7 and S8), the structure of 57 was similar to that of 56, except for isopentenyl cyclisation. Undoubtedly, a pyranoid ring was formed by the coupling constant value ( J ′′ 3,4 ′′ = 10.1 Hz) and corresponding chemical shifts ( δ C 127.3 at C-3 ′′ and δ C 115.7 at C-4 ′′ ). Therefore, the structure of 57 was constructed, and named bavachinone G.

Bavachinone I ( 59 ) possessed the molecular formula C 17 H 16 O 5 , revealing 10 degrees of unsaturation. The NMR spectra (Tables S7 and S8) showed the classical flavonone signals. However, NMR signals of the isopentenyl group were not observed. Further analysis showed that a methyl group was added on C-7 via the HMBC correlation from CH 3 at δ H 3.88 to C-7 at δ C 165.5 ( Fig. 2 ). The cross-peaks between CH 2 OH at δ H 4.55 and C-5 at δ C 126.0/C-7 indicated that a hydroxymethyl group was linked to C-6. Thus, the structure of 59 was established, as shown in Fig. 1 .

Bavachinone J ( 60 ) had the molecular formula C 21 H 24 O 7 . Upon combining its NMR data (Tables S7 and S8), it was inferred that compound 60 was a flavonone. A methyl group was combined on C-7 by the key HMBC correlation from CH 3 at δ H 3.83 to C-7 at δ C 165.1 ( Fig. 2 ). Three hydroxyl groups were added at C-1 ′′ , C-2 ′′ , and C-3 ′′ via chemical shifts at δ C 68.0, 78.5, and 75.1 and HMBC correlations. According to the coupling constant value ( J ′′ 1,2 ′′ = 3.7 Hz) (
), the configurations of OH-1 ′′ and OH-2 ′′ were assigned erythro . In this way, we established the structure of 60, and named it bavachinone J.

Psorachalcone C ( 75 ), a yellow amorphous powder, was assigned the molecular formula C 21 H 24 O 7 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data (Table S9) showed that compound 75 was a chalcone. Singlet proton signals at δ H 8.17 (1H, s) and δ H 6.24 (1H, s) assigned to the A ring determined it as a 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted benzene ring. A methyl group was added on C-4 ′ via HMBC cross-peaks between CH 3 at δ H 3.70 and C-4 ′ at δ C 167.0 ( Fig. 2 ). Hydroxyl substitutions occurred at C-1 ′′ , C-2 ′′ and C-3 ′′ by their chemical shifts at δ C 68.5, 78.5 and 75.3, respectively. The configurations of OH-1 ′′ and OH-2 ′′ were determined to be erythro based on the broad single peak characteristics (
) of H-1 ′′ and H-2 ′′ in the 1 H NMR spectrum. Accordingly, the structure of 75 was constructed.

Bavaflavone A ( 94 ) was isolated as a yellow amorphous powder and assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 18 O 6 on the basis of HR-ESI-MS at m/z 355.1186 [M + H] + (calcd for 355.1182). The flavone nature of compound 94 was supported by representative NMR signals (Table S10) at δ C 184.7 for C-4 and δ C 148.2 for C-2. Ortho-coupling proton signals ( J = 8.5 Hz) at δ H 7.58 and δ H 6.70 were assigned to ring A, which was supported by the key HMBC correlation between H-5 at δ H 7.58 and C-4 at δ C 184.7 ( Fig. 2 ). Additionally, we also observed a group of 1,3,4- trisubstituted benzene ring signals at δ H 7.52, δ H 7.22 and δ H 6.83 belonging to ring B. Furthermore, HMBC correlations from H-1 ′′ at δ H 3.38 to C-9 at δ C 164.3 indicated that an isopentenyl group was added on C-8. Isopentenyl was cyclised to a dihydrofuran ring through C 2 ′′–O–C 7 on the basis of carbon chemical shifts ( δ C 93.5 at C-2 ′′ and δ C 27.7 at C-3 ′′ ) and 12 degrees of unsaturation. A hydroxyl group was added on C-4 ′′ via HMBC correlations between CH 3 -5 ′′ /6 ′′ at δ H 1.33/1.28 and C-4 ′′ at δ C 72.6. Accordingly, the structure of 94 was established and its’ absolutely configuration was confirmed as 2 ′′ R by the optical value ([ α ]25 D 74.4) (
).

Bavaisoflavanol ( 106 ) was isolated as a white amorphous powder, and its’ molecular formula was determined to be C 20 H 22 O 5 via HR-ESI-MS at m/z 341.1402 [M – H] – (calcd for 341.1389). A set of NMR signals (Table S12) for the – CH 2 - CH – CH – fragment at δ H 4.20 (1H, dd, J =17.5, 11.0 Hz), δ H 3.50 (1H, dd, J =17.5, 11.0 Hz), δ H 3.50 (1H, dd, J =11.0, 5.6 Hz) and δ H 5.44 (1H, br d, J =5.6 Hz) were present in the 1 H NMR spectrum, except for aromatic and isopentenyl signals. However, no carbonyl signal was observed. Therefore, the above NMR analysis indicated an isoflavanol skeleton for compound 106. Two singlet signals at δ H 7.17 and δ H 6.40 assigned to the A ring revealed the presence of an isopentenyl group on C-6. In addition, 1,2,4-trisubstituted aromatic ring signals were observed, and hydroxyl substitutions occurred at C-2 ′ and C-4 ′ on the basis of their chemical shifts at δ C 161.8 and δ C 159.6. Thus, the structure of 106 was established as shown in Fig. 1 . The absolute configuration was assigned as 3 S ,4 R from positive Cotton effects in the CD curve at 238 nm (Δ ε 8.74) and 290 nm (Δ ε +2.95) ( Fig. S5 ) (
).

sec.title: 2.2. Osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation activities of MC3T3-E1
sec.p: The cell viability of 89 compounds was assessed using the MTT method. As shown in Table S15, most compounds showed noncytotoxicity in the range of 0.001–20 μ M after 48 h of administration. According to the results of preliminary screening, the compounds were effective at 0.1, 1, and 10 μ M. Therefore, we chose the three concentrations for activity evaluation, and selected E2 at 0.1 μ M as the positive control. However, compounds 51, 115 and 116 showed cytotoxicity after 7 or 16 days of induction, as determined from low total protein concentrations and poor cell morphologies under a microscope.

We evaluated the effects of 17 coumarins on osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation. As shown in Fig. 4 , Fig. S12 and Table S16, compounds 16 (psoralen) and 17 (isopsoralen) led to a two-fold increase of the amount of calcium nodules at concentrations of 1 and 10 μ M. Further, the activity (240.72 ± 9.43%; 224.59 ± 10.19% activation compared with control) of compound 17 was stronger than that of compound 16 (203.17 ±10.52%; 196.98 ±6.36% activation compared with control), which was probably due to similar structures between angular furanocoumarin and estrogen. However, only compound 16 increased ALP expression at 0.1 μ M at day 7. When the lactone ring was opened to form compounds 101 and 102, or compounds 122 and 123 by further glycosylation (Fig. S11), the mineralisation activity disappeared. This indicated that the furanocoumarin skeleton was necessary for activity. Compound 11 (coumestrol) significantly promoted the osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation of MC3T3-E1 cell at 10 μ M. However, a methoxyl substitution ( 12 ) at C-5 ′ of 11 resulted in reduction in its mineralisation ability. Interestingly, the replacement of the isopentenyl group at C-5 ′ to produce compound 13 (psoralidin) resulted in a two-fold increase in ALP and calcium nodules at 0.1 μ M. However, changes at the isopentenyl group, including, but not limited to, hydroxylation and cyclisation, led to a decreased or an absent activity. Hydroxylation substituents ( 6 ) and cyclisation to form dihydrofuran (7, 8, 9 and 2), resulted in a reduced activities. When forming furan ( 1 ), six-membered (14 and 15) and seven-membered rings ( 4 ), showed no activity, possibly due to larger molecule sizes preventing access to the estrogen-binding pocket. In summary, compared with that in 11, isopentenyl replacement for 13 contributed to a strong activity.

The abilities of 28 isoflavones to induce osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation were assessed. As indicated in Fig. S8, Fig. S13 and Table S16, compound 44 (daidzein) showed a significant effect at 10 μ M, but a hydroxyl group ( 45 ) at C-3 ′ was unfavorable for the activity. It was noteworthy that a methoxyl (46, 3 ′ -methoxydaidzein) or an isopentenyl group (42, neobavaisoflavone) replacement at C-3 ′ promoted osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation at 0.1 and 1 μ M. However, structural changes in the isopentenyl group displayed a decreased or no activity. Compound 47, a hydroxylation product, was still able to increase the number of calcium nodules and the expression of ALP at 0.1 and 1 μ M, cyclised compounds (19, 20, 18, 35, 22, 20, 34, 41, 38, and 40) were almost inactive. When the isopentenyl group was combined with C-6 or C-8 (36, 23, 24, and 52), their activities disappeared or only ALP expression was increased, suggesting that the position of isopentenyl played a key role in osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation activities. Compared with 44, the introduced geranyl group (49, corylifol A) at C-3 ′ resulted in a stronger activity at 0.1 and 1 μ M. When a hydroxyl group was connected to the C-5 position of 49, the activity of 48 was retained at 1 μ M. Remarkably, when the geranyl group was hydroxylated or cyclised, and the terminal isopentenyl group remained intact, compounds 37 (neocorylin), 29, and 30 still promoted osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation at 0.1 and 1 μ M. These results showed that the terminal isopentenyl group of the geranyl moiety was conducive to their activity. However, simultaneous introduction of two isopentenyl groups at C-3 ′ and C-5’ ( 51 ) did not increase the activity, but increased cytotoxicity at 10 μ M, probably due to the larger molecular size and stronger adsorption to biofilms. In brief, compounds with methoxyl, intact isopentenyl or geranyl groups introduced at C-3 ′ displayed improved activities. Moreover, compound 108 (Fig. S11), an isoflavone glycoside, also showed a better activity at 0.1–10 μ M.

We investigated the effects of 14 flavonones on the osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation of MC3T3-E1cells. As indicated in Fig. S9, Fig. S14 and Table S16, compound 110 (bavachin) enhanced ALP expression and the amount of calcium nodules at 0.1 μ M. A methyl group introduced on 7-OH (111, bavachinin) showed a little effect on activity. However, the hydroxyl substituent at C-3, C-5 or C-3 ′ resulted in a decreased activity for compounds 58, 64, and 69. Similar results were obtained upon hydroxylation and cyclisation (72, 60, 56, 63, 55 and 53) of the isopentenyl group. When isopentenyl was combined with C-8 (70 and 68) or C-3’ ( 67 ), activities were weaker than those of compounds with the isopentenyl group at C-6. This indicated that flavonones with an isopentenyl replacement at C-6 exhibited a strong activity.

In addition, the activities of 14 chalcones, five flavones and one chromone ( 103 ) were evaluated. As shown in Fig. S10, Fig. S11 and Table S16, these types of compounds exhibited a weak activity. Among chalcones, only compound 112 (isobavachalcone), promoted the osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation of MC3T3-E1 cells at 0.1 μ M. Most flavones enhanced the expression of ALP at 10 μ M, and at the same time showed no effect or limitation on the formation of calcium nodules. However, flavone glycoside ( 109 ) (Fig. S11) could increase ALP expression and the amount of calcium nodules at 10 μ M. Unfortunately, there were insufficient data to further explain the SAR.

Furthermore, the activities of the eight meroterpenoids were investigated. Compound 114 (bakuchiol) significantly increase the formation (183.82 ±19.45% activation compared with control) of calcium nodules at 10 μ M (Fig. S11, Fig. S15 and Table S16). In most cases, structural changes in the monoterpene chain (115, 116, 117, 119 and 120) caused the activity to decrease or disappear. However, compound 118 (12- oxobakuchiol) exhibited a stronger activity with a 3-fold increased calcium nodules (300.69 ±15.26% at 10 μ M and 326.85 ±14.18% at 1 μ M), and enhanced ALP activities, which was probably contributed by the ketone group. Interestingly, compound 121, a cyclisation product, still showed effects on osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation at 10 μ M, which was attributed to the similarity between its 6/5/6 tricyclic system and that of estrogen structure.
2.3. Psoralidin and neobavaisoflavone work via ER pathway

To verify whether these compounds functioned via the ER pathway, representative compounds psoralidin ( 13 ) and neobavaisoflavone ( 42 ) were added to cells with ICI (0.1 μ M) treatment, an ER antagonist. As indicated in Fig. 5 , ICI decreased ALP activities and the calcium nodule formation in MC3T3-E1 cells exposed to E2 (0.1 μ M), psoralidin ( 13 ) (0.1 μ M) and neobavaisoflavone ( 42 ) (0.1 μ M). The above-mentioned results showed that these compounds promoted osteogenic differentiation and mineralisation of MC3T3-E1 cells via the ER pathway.
2.4. SPR analysis

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
In summary, diverse structures were obtained from the fruits of
P. corylifolia
, and 109 chemical constituents, containing 37 undescribed compounds, were reported in this study. The structures of undescribed compounds were elucidated via spectroscopic methods, single-crystal Xray diffraction, Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 and Mo 2 (OAc) 4 -ICD spectra. In addition, the wrong structures of the four known coumarins were corrected following X-ray crystallographic analysis. Systematic phytochemical investigations enabled us to establish the most comprehensive constituent library to date, covering over 180 compounds.

Further SAR analysis showed that compounds with intact isopentenyl replacement possessed superior activities than compounds without isopentenyl substitution, or compounds with an altered isopentenyl group. This was because the isopentenyl group increased their affinity for ER. Moreover, isoflavones with an isopentenyl group at C-3 ′ and flavonones with an isopentenyl group at C-6 exhibited better activities than compounds with isopentenyl groups at other positions.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
The mature fruits of
Psoralea corylifolia
L. (Leguminosae) was harvested in Yunnan Province (GPS coordinates:
23 ◦ 32 ′ N
,
99 ◦ 23 ′ E
), People’ s Republic of China in
October 2016
, and authenticated by Prof. XiuWei Yang of the School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Peking University. A voucher specimen (NO: BGZ201610 ) of the fruits was deposited at the State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines
and Biomimetic Drugs of Peking University
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: Detailed extraction and isolation processes could be viewed in Supplementary data. Spectroscopic data of 37 undescribed compounds and NMR data of 72 known compounds were shown in Supplementary data.

sec.title: 4.4. Mo 2 (OAc) 4 and Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 -induced CD spectra
sec.p: Compounds ( 0.6 mg ) were dissolved in anhydrous DMSO solution of 1 mg /mL Mo 2 (OAc) 4 or Rh 2 (OCOCF 3 ) 4 . After mixing, the ICD spectrum was immediately collected from 250 nm to 500 nm until a stable state.

sec.title: 4.5. X-ray crystallographic analysis
sec.p: The X-ray crystallographic data was collected on a Rigaku Micro Max 003+ single crystal diffractometer with CuK α radiation and a XtaLAB Synergy R, HyPix diffractometer with CuK α radiation. Crystallographic data for 1 (No. CCDC 2102008), 7 (No. CCDC 2102007), 8 (No. CCDC 2102009) and 33 (No. CCDC 2102010) have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (the detailed X-ray Crystallographic analysis data see Table S14). These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html.

sec.title: 4.6. Cultivation and osteogenic differentiation of MC3T3-E1 cells
4.7. Cell viability
sec.p: MC3T3-E1 cells were seeded in 96-well culture plates at a density of 1 × 10 4 cells/well for 24 h. And then, cells were treated with compounds at various concentrations (20, 10, 1.0, 0.1, 0.01 and 0.001 μ M) in the osteogenic differentiation medium. After 48 h, cell viability was assessed by the MTT method.

sec.title: 4.8. ALP activity assay
sec.p: MC3T3-E1 cells were cultivated in osteogenic differentiation medium with compounds (10.0, 1.0 and 0.1 μ M) and E2 (0.1 μ M) for 7 days. Cell lysis buffer for Western and IP without inhibitors (100 μL) was added into each well and the cells were lysed on ice for 10 min. The total protein collection was obtained after centrifugation at 12,000× g for 3 min and was diluted five times for ALP activity assay. The concentration of the total protein collection was measured by BCA method.

sec.title: 4.9. Calcium nodules staining and quantitation
sec.p: MC3T3-E1 cells were cultivated in osteogenic differentiation medium with compounds (10.0, 1.0 and 0.1 μ M) and E2 (0.1 μ M) for 16 days. The cells were fixed by 4% paraformaldehyde fix solution (1 mL) for 30 min. Next, calcium nodules were stained by Alizarin Red S (ARS) for 5 min. Pictures of staining sample were taken by an inverted optical microscope and a digital camera. Finally, calcium nodules were dissolved for 30 min at room temperature by 10% cetylpyridinium chloride monohydrate, and the amount was quantified by absorbance values at 570 nm .

sec.title: 4.10. SPR analysis for binding affinity
sec.p: SPR experiment was performed by Biacore 8K (GE Healthcare). Recombinant Human Estrogen Receptor β protein was diluted to 20 μg/mL with sodium acetate solution. The PSP-P buffer was used for mobile phase. According to standard operation, the diluted protein was coupled to CM5 sensor chip. At flow rate at 20 μL/min, the binding time was 60 s and the dissociation time was 130 s. The sensor chip surface was regenerated with 10 mM NaOH. Finally, data was analyzed using Biacore 8K software.
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (81773865).

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113085.
